The point is what will fix the economy that most of us have to live with. Painless? Of course not. But the status quo hurts the vast majority, while only benefiting the tip of the top. And you want more of that?

Incidentally, when my parents were able to sell the home they'd lived in for over 40 years for enough to finance a large chunk of their retirement, you think that happened by prices going down or staying the same? You think it was a horrible thing? They didn't. I don't.

While one might agree that the very rich, in gaining ever more riches, will eventually hurt the vitality of the overall economic system, I don't think there's much danger that the very rich, themselves, will be hurt, either short or long term, by their gaining more and more riches. They are immune to any negative consequences because they control not only the means of wealth creation but also control the forces that protect that wealth creation: the courts, the legislatures, the regulators, and thus the various police agencies.

There really isn't any institution left which the less that rich can turn to to counterbalance the protected power of the rich.

Logic is not their guide. Accumulation and Power is their guide. As they have transferred and grown more powerful, they then go after the 1-10% below. This is not a game played by but sociopaths and psychopaths. Each smite for them is exciting.

None of the oligarchs realize that luck and chance are involved in wins. They do really believe that they're better and harder working and deserve what they have. This is a stratgey no different than chess. It is not seen as it really is, Monopoly. Complaint and suggestions to share are dismissed as deranged.

In a way I think some of the people (policy makers and the 0.1 percent) who keep hailing conventional wisdom lack foresight and guts. They fail to understand low inflation will eventually hurt them when the pie keeps getting smaller and it is definitely unwise to keep the vast majority of people around them poor when their lavish lifestyle is up for public display. By sticking to the status quo, they're trying to protect their short term well-being by forgoing the long term vitality of the overall system. It's a safe short term bet but a stupid and risky long term bet.

No, very few of us have pensions. We have savings which produce no income.
A modest rate of inflation and a return to 5% interest rates, rewards both those who played by the rules and saved, and stimulates the economy helping most others. There is no scenario which helps everyone.

Academia Nut,

You are taking both sides of the issue. On the one hand, you are saying that studies are more reliable than personal anecdotes. On the other, you are gainsaying countless studies saying that exercise increases endorphin levels, using a personal anecdote.

"to hurt your back or your knee or Achilles tendon and take a month off to recover"
Actually, this indicates that exercise is not good for you, but bad for you.
Just about everybody I know that ran or regularly did moderately-intensive exercise for an extended period eventually had to stop or dramatically cut back due to orthopedic injuries. In other words, they seriously harmed themselves. It is like smoking--if you do it long enough, you harm yourself.
This is better health?
No, it is what keeps whole orthopedic hospitals and departments and doctors' practices economically viable and puts a lot of people in expensive cars.
Understand that we now have whole occupations and a multi-billion-per-year exercise/medical industrial complex whose job it is to sustain the myth that exercise=health when in reality, for most people, exercise=harm.
Can you name any part of the body where long-term stress does not lead to harm? Why should the cardiovascular system be any different?
(E.g. look up exercise and Afib in the recent medical literature...)

Don't you think that orthopedic " doctors, nutritionists, physical therapists, dietitians, personal trainers" and exercise-facility-investors have a strong personal financial interest in perpetuating this myth? Follow the money.

If it turned out that stressing body parts actually led to harm, rather than health somehow, do you expect the medical establishment to admit that they were wrong? It is extremely difficult to admit that you were wrong for decades. But every orthopedic procedure done on exercisers it like an event caused by smoking.

Take a look at the Look AHEAD randomized control trial results, not observational studies flawed by reverse causality. What do the say is the definition of insanity, when you keep trying the same thing over and over and expect to get different results?

Poor parenting is not just a behavior of uneducated, low-income parents. I know of educated, upper-middle-class people who do not show affection and attention to their children, and do not talk to them very much. Nor do they read to their children.

So perhaps parenting education should be provided to inept or negligent parents from all strata of society. The question is how to identify such parents. Off the top of my head, the best approach I can think of is for schools or child protection agencies to identify children who are psychologically troubled (e.g., violent, extremely anxious or depressed) and investigate what is going on in the family. Then provide whatever help is needed to help poor parents become better parents.

However, this is unlikely to happen. Given the cases of horrendous physical abuse we see – cases that were overlooked by child protection agencies – it's hard to imagine society spending the resources to help children who are emotionally and intellectually deprived but not physically abused.

Agreed, but in terms of priority we need to think first about mandating an end to our trade imbalance. Unlike in the Post WWII era stimulating consumer demand no longer puts idle factories back to full production here, creating jobs in the U.S. It  instead increases factory jobs in China and India while our own people remain unemployed. Some of us believe that this dilemma only can be resolved by granting $ trade credits to U.S. exporters (who create jobs here) and by compelling would-be importers to buy those credits on regulated exchange before being able to release equivalent $ to pay for their imports. That would balance trade, while at the same time encouraging importers to look for supply source here (creating jobs here.)

There has definitely been a demographic shift in NYC. Our building, whose long-term residents were mostly middle-income, many musicians, academics, etc. of various ages, had a community feel and was a bit on the quirky side - perhaps a bit like "Seinfeld."
That community feel is disappearing quickly as affluent finance and media folks move in. They are not interested in quirky.(They also do not treat the building staff respectfully.)
Sad to see the impact of "hyper" gentrification.

Visited my mother this weekend in her NYC apartment building. For many decades this building (and the entire complex of 10+ buildings) were very quiet, mostly occupied by middle class native New Yorkers who raised their children in the complex and then stayed on in their rent controlled apartments, usually until they die. Few children, few young people.

My mother pays market rent, having only moved there six years ago, but her sister has lived there since 1962.

Now under different management, most of the units are rented at full market price by the new New Yorkers -- people from all over who've come to NYC to make a (big) buck in finance and related lines of work.

At 10:30 pm Saturday night as my elderly mother tried to sleep, the neighbors were SOCIALIZING IN THE HALL outside our door with their children shrieking and running.

I waited a minute, the noise continued, so I opened the door to see two couples yakking away as their kids cavorted. I had to tell them that they were bothering us, and I couldn't help adding that "this is NOT A DORM" and that "apartment buildings have social norms which you may not be aware that you are violating."

The noise stopped.

The next morning as my mother and went out, of course we encountered them in the foyer, where frosty looks were shot in our direction. Sigh.

Chad, no wonder, we get sighed at, rolled eyes at and corrected by our millennials, for every politically incorrect statement we make! Ah so! We thought they are ultra sensitive, now we realize they want to be inclusive to every opinion. Looks like President Obama gets this generation. To many older people, highly opinionated, the President comes across as unsure, not strong enough, not loud enough, when all along he just wanted every voice to be heard, included and respected.

Chad, I'm thinking that that's because you were overprotected by helicopter parents. See the recent article in the Atlantic for a description of the harm those rubber playgrounds and constant adult supervision has done to your generation. Then, read a few of Franklin Roosevelt's speeches.

We boomers are old enough to remember a time when the government of this country worked for the people, rather than for Wall Street. When every American could look forward to a better living than his parents. When the country didn't shy away from doing great things. And that didn't happen by itself.

Where would be today if Martin Luther King hadn't been of the opinion that black Americans shouldn't be treated as second-class citizens? If Abraham Lincoln hadn't been of the opinion that slaver should be abolished? Or if George Washington hadn't been of the opinion that the country should be independent, and once it was, a republic rather than a monarchy?

None of these were exactly popular opinions. Firebombs and dogs, a civil war, a revolution. Were these men cautious? The thousands who risked their lives to support them?

These "strident young voices" come largely from those most polarized, eager to incite argument over dialogue. As college students, we bear this in mind before we post, tweet, or chain-email, and then (painfully) redact much of our subjective tone that make us who we are, thereby masking our true selves seen only privately among close friends. But today we're wise to acknowledge those we don't know who have the indices to know us dearly, such as a future employer. Michael Lynch, when writing earlier about our loss of privacy, saw this issue as a detrimental loss to our autonomous selves.

Our personalities are gone amidst this rigid, 21st century pluralistic etiquette, not for fear of being ridiculed, but for risk of seeming "extreme". To firmly express opinions and expect none of them to draw controversy is akin to tweeting axioms at our professors and hoping they consider all our thoughts wise without refuting them openly in class, or worse, on blog. Fear is, unfortunately, a powerful motivator, and an even greater censor; so I agree, we're not apathetic, but rightly cautious.

@common sense - I'm no economic expert but I do remember the days when moderate inflation, progressive taxation with high marginal rates, 5% interest guaranteed for bank savings accounts, and modest gains in the Dow Jones all worked together in an economy for the benefit of the average person, who prospered much more than now. Now, bank interest is so insultingly low that those who can save anything (a decreasing portion of the population) are forced to risk their savings in the stock market casino to get any kind of return at all. Probably like most retirees among the 99%, I'm very conservative about risk, and I dread another shock like 2008. On balance, I would accept a modest increase in inflation in return for greater stability.

The financial community knows how to make money from both the good fortune and the misfortune of others, and I think the whole economy has been warped just to steer people away from stable savings vehicles and into the stock market. It's no accident that the 0.1% proper exceedingly even as the middle class stagnates or even regresses.

Class interest writ large.
